availability.p: The British Academic Written English (BAWE) corpus was developed at the Universities of Warwick, Reading and Oxford Brookes, under the directorship of Hilary Nesi and Sheena Gardner (formerly of the Centre for Applied Linguistics [previously called CELTE], Warwick), Paul Thompson (Department of Applied Linguistics, Reading) and Paul Wickens (Westminster Institute of Education, Oxford Brookes), with funding from the ESRC. Subject to the rights of the these institutions in the BAWE corpus, and pursuant to the ESRC agreement, the BAWE corpus is available to researchers for research purposes PROVIDED THAT the following conditions are met:
1. The corpus files are not distributed in either their original form or in modified form.
2. The texts are used for research purposes only; they should not be reproduced in teaching materials.
3. The texts are not reproduced in full for a wider audience/readership, although researchers are free to quote short passages of text (up to 200 running words from any given text).
4. The BAWE corpus developers (contact: Hilary Nesi) are informed of all projects, dissertations, theses, presentations or publications arising from analysis of the corpus.

5. Researchers acknowledge their use of the corpus using the following form of words: "The data in this study come from the British Academic Written English (BAWE) corpus, which was developed at the Universities of Warwick, Reading and Oxford Brookes under the directorship of Hilary Nesi and Sheena Gardner (formerly of the Centre for Applied Linguistics [previously called CELTE], Warwick), Paul Thompson (Department of Applied Linguistics, Reading) and Paul Wickens (Westminster Institute of Education, Oxford Brookes), with funding from the ESRC (RES-000-23-0800)."

note.resp: British Academic Written English (BAWE) corpus project

p.n: number of paragraphs formatted like lists

titlePage.titlePart: Group A Physical Laboratory A Report 10/03/2005

p.s: Density is defined as mass/volume;
Specific Gravity is (mass of substance)/(mass of an equally volume of water).
The aim of these experiments is to measure particle density(or solid density), bulk density and porosity for apple, potato, peas and dried milk powder.
In this lab report, I recorded the following 4 experiments:

list.item: Apple - Density, Average Diameter and Volume
Potato - Density, Average Diameter and Volume
Dried Peas - Particle Density, Bulk Density and Porosity
Dried Milk Powder - Bulk Density, Particle Density and Porosity

div2.head: Apple - Density and Volume (displaced in water)

p.s: The diameter of apple was measured in several directions.
(See table below)
As we know the equation for the volume of a spherical particle is: V = 4/3 π r3
Where r is the Average Radius of the apple
Substitute the r into the equation and assume this apple is spherical:
As we measured, the mass of that apple is 149.05g.
In that case, the Density of apple is:
However, the shape of apple is not spherical.
In order to get a more accurate volume and density of the apple, the volume of the apple can be calculated by the amount of water it displaces. (the density of water is 1000 kg m -3)
This time we get the Density of apple is:

div2.head: Potato - Density and Volume (displaced in water)

p.s: The diameter of potato was measured in several directions.
(See table below)
The average diameter is 7.42cm, so the average radius is:
Assume this potato is spherical, and the equation known as: V = 4/3 π r3
As we measured, the mass of this potato is 210.96g.
In that case, the Density of potato is:
As we mentioned above, the shape of potato is not spherical.
In order to get a more accurate volume and density of the potato, the volume of the potato can be calculated by the amount of water it displaces. (the density of water is 1000 kg m -3)
This time we get the Density of potato is:

div2.head: Dried Peas - Particle Density, Bulk Density and Porosity

p.s: The diameter of one pea is measured in several direction.
(See table below)
The average diameter is 0.72cm, so the average radius is:
Assume this pea is spherical, and the equation known as: V = 4/3 π r3
As we measured, the mass of this pea is 0.009g
So that it seems to be the Particle Density of this pea is:
As we mentioned above, the shape of pea is not spherical.
In order to get a more accurate Densities, we use a number of peas and displace them into water.
See table below shows when we measure a number of peas:
The Particle Density of peas is:
The Bulk Density of peas is calculated by placing a known mass of material in a measuring cylinder and compacting it until a constant volume is obtained, which is 38ml and including air.
The Bulk Density of peas is: ρb = mass / bulk volume
The porosity (ε) of a number peas can be calculated by the following equation:
The peas were then be boiled in water for 15 minutes and their volume as well as particle and bulk density were recorder and calculated.
The porosity of those boiled peas can be calculated using:

div2.head: Dried Milk Powder - Bulk Density, Particle Density and Porosity

p.s: In order to calculate the bulk density of the dried milk powder 20g of milk powder was placed in a measuring cylinder and the cylinder was tapped gently until a constant volume was reached.
Determine the solid density using a specific gravity bottle:
As it followed by the Handbook:
Those values are measured and noted, see table below:
Therefore specific gravity of the solid is equal to:
The density of water is 1000kg/m 3, when a substance has a greater density than water, it will sink in water, where as those with less density than water will float in water.
In the first experiment, the result show the apple should sink in water, but as we discovered, apple usually float in water, which means the density of apple should be less than water.
In that case, the first way of calculating density is not accurate for apple is not spherical.
It is the same theory for the second experiment.
The density of a substance is equal to the mass of the substance divided by the volume that it occupies.
There might be still some errors exist.
The fact is, the density of a substance will change when the temperature is different.
'Density differences in heated fluids provide the driving force for natural convection.'
(Taken from the course book, page 52)
In a word, density decreases as a increasing in temperature.
Bulk density is the density of the bulk material under these conditions which include the volume of the air:
In comparison, while we calculate Particle density, we do not count the volume of the air.
Particle density refer to the density of an individual unit:
To be noticed, for the last experiment: Dried Milk Powder, the bulk density can be affected by the solids content of the feed, prior to drying and the suddenly inlet and outlet air temperatures.
Porosity is the fraction of the total volume taken up by air.
All in all, the relationship between porosity, bulk density and particle density is given by: Porosity ε =Volume of Air / Volume of Bulk sample
so:
In those experiments, we determined the density and specific gravity of a range of food by measuring the bulk density of solid and using specific gravity bottle to determine the particle density.
What's more, this report help me understand the difference of Bulk density and Particle density, and the relationship of them and porosity.

div1.head: Reference:
div1.p: Some of the information is taken from the course book:
'Physical Properties of Foods and Food Processing System'
Detailed Practical Methods and Background Material are learn by doing the laboratory and from the Supplementary Practical Handbook.
